image.altText: Map of temperatures anomalies in southern parts of South America

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Scientists in disbelief as temperatures soar to 37C in South America in the middle of winter

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks out to the audience, he wears a yellow tie with a suit

items.synopsis: The Voice debate has become far more complex than Anthony Albanese would have wanted it to be but his government is at risk of letting down the 'yes vote' by being too cautious, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese needs to be upfront about the Voice and treaty

image.altText: Promotional photo of singer and songwriter Keith Urban sitting with crossed legs and arms, looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Grammy award-winning country music star Keith Urban will be inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame, one of songwriting's highest honours.

image.altText: Nigerian players celebrate

items.synopsis: The African and Caribbean nations have qualified for the Women's World Cup knock-outs, but their success belies the challenges they've been battling back home.

image.altText: aerial of wind farm

items.synopsis: A group of traditional owners is taking its fight to Canberra in a last-ditch effort to stop the $1 billion Chalumbin Wind Farm from being built adjacent to World Heritage-protected rainforests in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Traditional owners to take fight to Canberra over wind farm to be built near protected rainforests

image.altText: A black electric vehicle hooked up to a Tesla charging station

items.synopsis: Electric Vehicle Council finds Australia's transition is lagging behind countries including China and Thailand due to "outdated" regulations.

title.children: EV strategy has to accelerate, says report, as Australia falls behind

image.altText: Two kids jump in the air in a hug will two others look on across a country football ground

title.children: In one of the smallest football competitions in Australia, even the ABC is forced to fill in

items.synopsis: Claims have spread consistently for years online that 2,030 people died as a result of the Robodebt scheme. But does that number align with the facts?

title.children: Did 2,030 people really die as a result of the Robodebt scheme?

image.altText: Diamonds goal-attack Kiera Austin rubs her chin while standing on the court during a Netball World Cup match against England.

items.synopsis: Australia thumped England 3-0 in a Test series last year and it seems the lessons learned and experience garnered by the Roses cost the Diamonds on the biggest stage, writes Brittany Carter.

title.children: How thrashing England last year came back to bite Australia at the Netball World Cup

image.altText: patches of snow on grass with ski lifts overhead

items.synopsis: Unseasonable warmth has been persistent across much of Australia for weeks, but intensified temperatures and unusual heat are becoming more regular.

title.children: Australia thaws in mid-winter warmth — is winter over?

image.altText: A statue inscription.

items.synopsis: A team of visiting experts from Cambodia say there are hundreds of "stolen" artefacts in three of Australia's top museums, as well as in private collections.

title.children: Two more Australian museums in possession of 'stolen' antiquities

image.altText: Person in red shit and beige hat fills up water bottle

items.synopsis: At least 600 scouts from across the globe have fallen ill in South Korea, where a heatwave is gripping the nation.

title.children: Hundreds of scouts fall ill amid South Korean heatwave

image.altText: Murphy Yunupingu sits smiling in a grey shirt in the shade

items.synopsis: Garma began as a family gathering and grew to become the largest meeting place of First Nations peoples in the country. Here, the festival's founding family reflects on what the event means to them.

title.children: 'This is bush parliament': Thousands to gather for the annual Garma Festival

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

items.synopsis: Australia's competition watchdog has rejected ANZ's proposed takeover of Suncorp's bank, while local traders await the RBA's latest statement on monetary policy. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's the latest from Michael Janda who has been reading through the Reserve Bank's quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy (SOMP): The Reserve Bank has moved into 'wait and see' mode on interest rates as it weighs up an economy where risks are "broadly balanced" between a stubborn inflation breakout and a recession, with the hope of engineering a soft landing in between those extremes. The August statement has given more detail about why Australia's central bank chose to leave interest rates on hold this month, surprising many economists. One thing is clear — the decision not to raise rates further was again a close call. "At both the July and August meetings, the board considered the option of raising rates further," the SOMP observed. "The board's current assessment is that the risks around the inflation outlook are broadly balanced. "But it recognises that the crystallisation of upside risks would increase the likelihood of inflation staying high for longer and a rise in medium-term inflation expectations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA in 'wait and see' mode: SOMP

children.content: Here's the latest from
Michael Janda
who has been reading through the
Reserve Bank's quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy
(SOMP):

The Reserve Bank has moved into 'wait and see' mode on interest rates as it weighs up an economy where risks are "broadly balanced" between a stubborn inflation breakout and a recession, with the hope of engineering a soft landing in between those extremes.
The August statement has given more detail about why Australia's central bank chose to leave interest rates on hold this month, surprising many economists.
One thing is clear — the decision not to raise rates further was again a close call.
"At both the July and August meetings, the board considered the option of raising rates further," the SOMP observed.
"The board's current assessment is that the risks around the inflation outlook are broadly balanced.
"But it recognises that the crystallisation of upside risks would increase the likelihood of inflation staying high for longer and a rise in medium-term inflation expectations."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has just released its quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy, which includes its latest economic forecasts. The RBA now expects economic growth to slow to 0.9 per cent this year, down from 1.2 per cent previously forecast. Headline inflation is tipped to ease to 4.1 per cent by year-end. Michael Janda has been in the RBA's lock up getting across all the detail so we'll bring you more very shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank trims growth, inflation forecasts

children.content: The Reserve Bank has just released its
quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy
, which includes its latest economic forecasts.
The RBA now expects economic growth to slow to 0.9 per cent this year
, down from 1.2 per cent previously forecast.
Headline inflation is tipped to ease to 4.1 per cent by year-end.
Michael Janda
has been in the RBA's lock up getting across all the detail so we'll bring you more very shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The banks at the centre of the ACCC 's decision to block a takeover deal, ANZ and Suncorp, have issued statements to the stock exchange. ANZ shares are up 0.6 per cent in early trade. Boss Shayne Elliott said ANZ is "naturally disappointed and disagree with the ACCC's decision". "We believe the acquisition will improve competition, which will benefit Australian consumers, particularly in Queensland," Mr Elliott said in the ASX statement. ANZ also noted that decisions by the ACCC could be reviewed by the Australian Competition Tribunal. And in the meantime, it "continues its preparations for the integration of Suncorp Bank into ANZ". Meanwhile, Suncorp shares are now down 1.9 per cent after the news. Suncorp chair Christine McLoughlin says the bank is "surprised and disappointed" and would "fully support" ANZ if it referred the decision to the Australian Competition Tribunal. "… we believe the Tribunal will accept the merits of our case," she said. Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has also noted the decision, saying the government "respects the independence of the ACCC and does not intend to comment further on the decision or the future of the proposal", but noted that there is the option for the banks to take the decision to the Tribunal or Federal Court. So … watch this space!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ, Suncorp respond to blocked takeover deal

children.content: The banks at the centre of the
ACCC
's decision to block a takeover deal,
ANZ
and
Suncorp
, have issued statements to the stock exchange.
ANZ shares are up 0.6 per cent in early trade.
Boss
Shayne Elliott
said ANZ is "naturally disappointed and disagree with the ACCC's decision".
"We believe the acquisition will improve competition, which will benefit Australian consumers, particularly in Queensland," Mr Elliott said in the ASX statement.
ANZ also noted that
decisions by the ACCC could be reviewed by the Australian Competition Tribunal
And in the meantime, it "continues its preparations for the integration of Suncorp Bank into ANZ".
Meanwhile, Suncorp shares are now down 1.9 per cent after the news.
Suncorp chair Christine McLoughlin
says the bank is "surprised and disappointed" and would "fully support" ANZ if it referred the decision to the Australian Competition Tribunal.
"… we believe the Tribunal will accept the merits of our case,"
she said.
Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers

has also noted the decision, saying the government "respects the independence of the ACCC and does not intend to comment further on the decision or the future of the proposal", but noted that there is the option for the banks to take the decision to the Tribunal or Federal Court.
So … watch this space!

image.altText: ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold.

items.synopsis: An ACT government spokeswoman confirms they will release the report earlier than planned, but says it is disappointing it was released by the board of inquiry to some media outlets outside of government procedures.

title.children: ACT government bows to pressure and will release report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution next week

image.altText: A middle-aged white man with low vision looking at a computer screen through a magnifying glass

title.children: 'Massive safety risk': Alarm bells ring for NDIS participants after data breach

image.altText: Pop singer Lizzo appears on stage.

items.synopsis: Grammy-winning pop star Lizzo labels claims of sexual harassment made against her by former dancers "false" and "outrageous".

title.children: 'Too outrageous to not be addressed': Lizzo responds to sexual harassment lawsuit

image.altText: Three Chinese police officers outside a court building.

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal a "contact point" linked to police in a Chinese city has gone online and remains operational in Australia. Similar operations have been investigated by US authorities for espionage, but Australian authorities remain unconcerned.

title.children: 'Tightly organised network': China using cloud-based tech to provide police services in Australia

image.altText: A large set of drones is pictured inside a big warehouse-like space.

items.synopsis: Iranian-made drones loaded with explosives leave a trail of destruction in Ukraine. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: How Iranian-made kamikaze drones became part of Russia's arsenal in its war with Ukraine
